in 0315

I called 
  IAction.setActionDefinitionId("org.eclipsercp.hyperbola.manageExtensions") 
where that command is not defined.  In the log I got a stack trace like

I realize that this is not a thrown exception but logging a full stack trace 
seems a bit harsh.  People seem to get somewhat distressed if their log 
contains anything at all.  since the system continues functioning just fine, it 
seems nothing should be logged.  Perhaps if -debug is on the trace should be 
logged.

I disagree.  This is potentially a subtle problem that can cause undesired
behaviour.  Catching the attention of the plug-in developer is important.

The error is only logged once per undefined command identifier.

I agree with that.  Catching the eye of the plugin devleoper is important.  
Catching the eye of the end user is bordering on counter-productive in this 
context.  

Example, we used to log messages whenever we found a plugin that was not 
resolved.  Very useful for developers.  However, many product configurations 
regularly ship with partial installs where some number of plugins are not 
resolved.  Users complained relentlessly that there was something wrong with 
their install.

In this case it seems that the two things are decoupled.  The fact that I set 
an actoin definition id that no one defined is a fine warning to the 
developer.  In a product however, the world might actually be configured that 
way on purpose.  Unless I am wrong, the system continues to work albeit without 
that particular command.  Right?

Continues to work, but items may appear in the menus that shouldn't.  Also, it
always points to a programmer error.  The action shouldn't reference a command
that hasn't been defined in one of its dependencies.
